abstract.p: David Fulton letter supports Leon Botstein Sept 19 Op-Ed article calling for more federal presence in education

block.p: Leon Botstein's arguments for more federal presence in education are on the money (Op-Ed, Sept. 19). If one were to try to construct the most inefficient, inequitable and unwieldy system of education in the world, it would be hard to outdo ours.

Leon Botstein's arguments for more federal presence in education are on the money (Op-Ed, Sept. 19). If one were to try to construct the most inefficient, inequitable and unwieldy system of education in the world, it would be hard to outdo ours.
Advocates of local control fear that the strings attached to greater federal financing will strangle local tastes, but the present system strangles the hopes of millions of children.

The most important question to ask is: Does child A, born into community A, have roughly the same opportunity for a quality education as child B, born into community B? For most industrialized countries, the answer is yes. For us, it's an embarrassing no. Our allegiance to local control, including our bizarre system of taxation, is the main culprit.
